description: Victory Square is Minsk's most significant memorial landmark, featuring a 38-meter granite obelisk crowned with a 3-meter replica of the Order of Victory. Built in 1954, this central square honors Soviet Army soldiers and Belarusian partisans who liberated Belarus from Nazi occupation during World War II. The square includes an eternal flame lit in 1961, an underground Memorial Hall with 566 Hero names, and soil capsules from 12 Soviet hero cities. Located at the intersection of Independence Avenue and Zakharau Street, it serves as both a solemn place of remembrance and an active social hub for parades, celebrations, and wedding photography.
highlights: The 38-meter granite obelisk with Order of Victory replica and Sacred Sword of Victory at its base
Eternal flame lit on July 3, 1961, by Hero of Soviet Union colonel-general Alexei Burdeinei
Four bronze wreaths representing the four Soviet fronts that liberated Belarus
Bronze relief panels depicting May 9 1945, Soviet Army, Belarusian Partisans, and Heroes
Underground Memorial Hall with 566 names of Heroes of Soviet Union and glass eternal flame representation
Granite blocks with soil capsules from 12 Soviet hero cities including Moscow, Volgograd, Kiev, and Brest Fortress
Changing of the Guard ceremony with Post #1 guards serving hourly shifts
Spectacular night illumination of the monument and square
tips: Visit the underground Memorial Hall in the pedestrian underpass - take the end without the escalator and walk 180 degrees until you see the 1941-45 memorial, then take the stairs
Look for the glass representation of the eternal flame underground to know you're directly beneath the surface flame
Time your visit for the Changing of the Guard ceremony, which occurs every hour (or every 15 minutes on Saturday mornings around 11am)
Visit both during daytime for detailed viewing and at night for dramatic lighting effects
Guards of honor serve from 9:00-17:00 in cold weather and 9:00-18:00 in warm weather, with 10-20 minute shifts
The square is easily accessible via Victory Square metro station on Independence Avenue
Combine your visit with nearby attractions: Red Church (Saints Simon and Helena), Gorky Park, Kupala Park, and Svisloch embankment
Observe the wedding tradition - newlyweds often stop to photograph at the eternal flame for good luck
vibe: Solemn, respectful, and deeply meaningful. Victory Square carries a palpable atmosphere of reverence where visitors feel compelled to show respect for the fallen soldiers. Despite being in the busy city center with traffic and daily bustle, people naturally adopt a quieter, more contemplative demeanor. The eternal flame creates a focal point for reflection, while the underground memorial intensifies the somber mood with its enclosed space and walls of Hero names. Yet the square also pulses with life as a social hub for celebrations, parades, and joyful wedding photos, creating a unique blend of mourning and celebration that defines post-war memorial culture.
expectations: A standard war memorial with a monument and flame
Just another Soviet-era square in the city center
Only relevant for history buffs or older generations
A quick photo stop that takes 10 minutes
reality: A multi-layered experience with an intricate underground Memorial Hall that many tourists miss entirely
An active social hub integrated into daily city life where memorialization and modern life coexist naturally
A bustling intersection on Independence Avenue with shops, cafes, and constant activity, yet maintaining a respectful atmosphere
Deeply meaningful to all generations - you'll see young couples, families, students, and elderly visitors all showing genuine reverence
Worth 30-60 minutes to properly explore the monument details, underground hall, guard ceremony, and surrounding area
unique_facts: The square was called 'Kruglaya' (Round Square) before 1958, changing its name to Victory Square after the monument's completion
The monument's four bronze wreaths represent the specific military fronts: 1st, 2nd, 3rd Belarusian and 1st Baltic
Post #1 was established on July 3, 1984, making it one of the honored guard posts in Belarus
The residential buildings with distinctive arch-shaped facades framing the square began construction in the late 1930s but were interrupted by WWII and completed post-war
Two additional hero city soil capsules (Smolensk and Murmansk) were added in 1985, one year after the original ten
The underground Memorial Hall opened exactly 40 years after Victory Day in 1985, creating a symbolic four-decade tribute
The glass eternal flame representation underground creates a unique mirror effect with the actual flame above
Wedding photography at the eternal flame has become such a tradition that the square sees dozens of newlywed couples weekly
surprises: The underground Memorial Hall exists at all - most tourists walk through the underpass without realizing there's a memorial chamber
The integration of war memorial with active city life - cafes, shops, and metro station create an unexpectedly vibrant atmosphere
The emotional impact is stronger than expected - even visitors without Soviet connections feel moved by the 566 Hero names
The night illumination transforms the monument completely, creating an almost ethereal appearance
The guard ceremony happens so frequently (every hour) that you don't need special timing to witness it
The soil capsules from hero cities are actual granite blocks you can touch, not just plaques or markers
The scale is more impressive in person - 38 meters plus the 3-meter Order of Victory makes it tower over the square
Local couples treat their wedding photo here as seriously as religious ceremony - you'll see brides in full gowns kneeling by the flame
The four bronze reliefs tell a complete narrative story if you walk around the entire pedestal - most people only see one or two panels
